awd_titl_txt: Sociocultural Approach to Integrating Computational Thinking and Data Analysis into an Online Citizen Science Program Linking Rural Educators in Maine, Mississippi, and Alabama
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will engage students in nine rural coastal schools in Maine, Mississippi, and Alabama, linking students around the Gulf of Maine with students near the Gulf of Mexico. This innovative approach of linking an online to classroom learning community will engage students in citizen science activities and will result in the design of curriculum modules that integrate computational thinking skills with standards-based instruction. An advisory group of teacher leaders, scientists, and a specialist in using computational analysis tools will co-design three learning modules for students and professional learning opportunities for teachers that will support classroom groups in developing investigations. The modules will use a data analysis tool designed specifically for students to integrate computational thinking skills with the citizen science investigations, enabling students to work with both existing, large-scale datasets related to their investigations, and local datasets that they and their peers have constructed. The project will also develop and implement a 3-day summer institute for teachers that will focus on inquiry-driven, place-based learning that integrates computational practices and thinking. Following each summer institute, participating teachers will work in teams to align a citizen science with components of computational thinking, with a focus on data collection and management, and data analysis. During the academic year, participating teachers, scientists, and participating community members will meet monthly to develop computational thinking skills, formulate questions to guide investigations, and consider topics related to student leadership, highlighting the work of scientists, and using science to inform actions. The modules to be developed and the supporting materials will be incorporated into learning management system that will be used to manage resources as well as facilitate interactions among students, teachers, scientists, and interested community members.

This project will use a design-based research approach to iteratively develop and test learning modules that engage students in computational thinking through active participation in citizen science investigations in school classrooms. This work will be guided by two research questions: 1) What are the key design elements and levels of implementation to consider when integrating computational data analysis skills in the context of place-based problem solving in co-designed citizen science in the classroom? And 2) What supports do rural educators need to increase their confidence and ability to teach computational data analysis in grades 3-8? To answer these questions, the project will: 1) Implement a co-design process to identify where and how computational thinking can be aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards and the Common Core State Standards for mathematics while addressing the unique needs and interests of rural schools and communities through citizen science involvement, 2) Develop a set of modules and associated professional development resources that support rural educators in using computational data analysis to interpret and share findings with peers and relevant communities, and 3) Identify ways to support rural educators in the implementation of computational thinking skills through the lens of citizen science, thereby making learning relevant and meaningful to students in their local communities. A range of classroom level data and student data, both quantitative and qualitative, will be collected to examine project impacts using ongoing, grounded theory-based analysis. 

This project is being supported jointly by the STEM+Computing program and the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program. As computing has become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the STEM+Computing program seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (PreK-12). This project will advance efforts of the ITEST program to better understand and promote practices that increase student motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by developing a technology-rich, out-of-school time STEM program for underserved middle and high school youth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Computational Thinking Through Citizen Science in the Classroom project was a response to the need from rural communities across the country for highly engaging learning experiences that integrate computational thinking across disciplines. This project focused on 9 rural coastal schools in Maine, Mississippi, and Alabama that connected via the online WeatherBlur community – linking the Gulf of Maine and the Gulf of Mexico – and reached over 1200 students. The development of this project emerged directly from the feedback and needs expressed by WeatherBlur educators who had become adept at the process of developing and carrying out scientific investigations but identified a key weakness in their skillset concerning working with and analyzing the data collected alongside their students and communities. Educators collaborated with project staff and the online data analysis tool, TUVA, to co-design curricular materials and professional development supports for the implementation of computational thinking in the classroom within the context of student-led, community-based citizen science projects. These materials focused on highlighting computational thinking skills that can be gained by integrating math standards (such as statistics and data literacy) with citizen science initiatives in the classroom. Through this project we achieved the following goals: 

  1. Generated a co-design process to identify where and how computational thinking can integrate into the Next Generation Science Standards and Math Common Core Standards while addressing the unique needs and interests of rural schools and communities through citizen science.

  2. Developed a set of modules and associated professional development that provides support for rural educators to move beyond collection of data to actually leveraging that data through computational data analysis to interpret their findings and share it with their peers and communities.  

  3. Identified how to support rural educators in the implementation of computational thinking skills through the lens of citizen science – making learning relevant and meaningful to a student’s community.

  4. Disseminated the findings of the project among a diverse audience including a mix of both the research and practitioner communities. 

The unique combination of rural regions and schools allowed us to make connections between the Gulf of Maine and the Gulf of Mexico and see the differences and similarities between these two geographic areas in the U.S. We connected with community partners at research facilities and universities in Maine, Mississippi, Alabama and North Carolina. This diverse group of teachers, students and scientific researchers provided a rich learning environment for all who were involved. Throughout the school year, teachers, students and scientific researchers were able to connect directly using the WeatherBlur website. We also held semiannual Zoom meetings where classrooms and scientific experts could meet together and share current classroom experiences and ask questions. These partnerships have resulted in dozens of co-created student-driven investigations and real-world datasets in Maine, Mississippi and Alabama. One small, rural, island school in the Gulf of Maine used this project to study the impacts of shoreline erosion on their local beach. Part of this investigation involved using historical satellite images and measurements at the beach to understand the impact of snow fencing and coastal grass planting on the shoreline. Students wrote a letter for a community grant to expand dune grass populations on the beach and have set up multiple continuous investigations to monitor the impact the grass has on erosion over time.  

During the course of this project, we were able to better understand how curriculum design and teacher professional development affect curriculum implementation within the context of computational thinking through a citizen science lens in rural spaces. We found that many rural teachers were adept at being a co-learner alongside their students as they designed real-world science investigations that addressed local community issues. These experiences with learning alongside their students, as well as rural community factors, such as administrative support and community value for place-based education, supported their ability to co-learn computational thinking connections alongside their students as well. Aligning professional development with the affordances of rural settings, such as connection to place and the natural environment through citizen science projects, can be effective for teachers to explore and integrate new concepts into their teaching. The WeatherBlur professional development strategy also supported teacher success by prioritizing social connections for rural educators. Teachers and support staff comprised a learning community that provided support and social encouragement, which enabled teachers to persist through difficulties. WeatherBlur program leaders facilitated these connections intentionally by providing synchronous and asynchronous space for regular discussion, collaboration, and support. We found this feature to be critically important for rural teachers–especially in early adoption–and believe that such a community bedrock should be a component of any professional development for rural educators.
